verses.sanskrit:
दुर्योधन उवाच ।
पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम् ।
व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता ॥
verses.transliteration:
duryodhana uvāca
paśyaitāṃ pāṇḍu-putrāṇām ācārya mahatīṃ camūm
vyūḍhāṃ drupada-putreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā
verses.translation: Duryodhana said: Behold, O Teacher, this mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by the son of Drupada — your wise disciple.

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana addresses Drona as 'Acharya' — Teacher — yet his speech is not that of a student. He points out that Dhrishtadyumna, the general of the Pandava forces, is Drona's own disciple. There is a subtle taunt here: your student has turned against you, and his army threatens us. Dadaji noted how worldly people exploit the most sacred relationships — the guru-shishya bond — for political purposes. Duryodhana is planting the seed of insecurity in Drona's mind, hoping to agitate him into fighting harder. This is the language of manipulation dressed as loyalty. True devotion to a teacher is unconditional; Duryodhana's 'respect' is entirely conditional on what Drona can do for him.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Duryodhana's opening word 'paśya' — behold — is charged with irony from the Vedantic standpoint. He commands his teacher to look, but only at the surface — at armies, numbers, formations. The very teacher he addresses is one who possesses the vision of higher knowledge, yet Duryodhana wishes to direct that vision toward the material battlefield alone. This is the fundamental confusion: using extraordinary faculties for ordinary ends. Vedanta reminds us that true seeing — darśana — is not the perception of armies and opponents but the recognition of the One Self in all. Duryodhana can only 'paśya' the army; he cannot see the Ātman.
commentary.yogananda: In the metaphysical interpretation, Duryodhana approaching Drona represents the ego-mind consulting the discriminating faculty in order to strengthen its position rather than transcend it. He says 'behold this mighty army' — the ego catalogues all the forces arrayed against it, not to understand them but to defeat them. Yogananda observed that the ego always takes inventory of its enemies. It measures and calculates. Yet this very measuring is the source of fear. The soul does not count armies; it rests in its own divine nature, unconcerned with the appearance of opposition.
commentary.goyandka: Duryodhana's reference to Dhrishtadyumna as 'tava śiṣyeṇa' — your disciple — is a precise and deliberate political maneuver. Classical commentators like Śrīdhara note that Duryodhana intends to goad Droṇācārya by reminding him that the opposing general was trained by Drona himself. The verse also establishes that the Pandava army, though placed under a disciple of Drona, is nonetheless formidable — described as 'mahatīm camūm,' a great army. The word 'dhīmatā' (wise, intelligent) for Dhrishtadyumna acknowledges his tactical skill even as it implies a challenge to Drona's loyalty.

verses.sanskrit:
अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि ।
युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः ॥
verses.transliteration:
atra śūrā maheṣvāsā bhīmārjuna-samā yudhi
yuyudhāno virāṭaś ca drupadaś ca mahārathaḥ
verses.translation: Here are great heroes, mighty archers, equal in battle to Bhima and Arjuna — Yuyudhana (Satyaki), Virata, and the great chariot-fighter Drupada.

word_breakdown.meaning: equal to Bhima and Arjuna (in battle)

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana lists the great warriors of the Pandava side, and each name carries a story. These are not strangers — they are family, former allies, beloved figures from childhood. Dadaji would say: look at what attachment to power does. These men who grew up together, who shared the same traditions, the same teachers, the same festivals — now they stand on opposite sides of the field. The tragedy of the Mahabharata is not the battle; it is the rupture of relationship that makes battle necessary. Every great warrior named here represents a bond broken by greed and pride.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Duryodhana compares these warriors to Bhima and Arjuna — the benchmarks of military excellence in his world. This comparison reveals how the ego evaluates everything by comparison, by ranking, by relative strength. 'How do they measure up? Are they equal? Are they greater?' The ego lives in the world of comparison. Vedanta points beyond comparison to the recognition of identity — not 'are they equal to Arjuna?' but 'is not the same Consciousness present in Arjuna and in all these warriors?' Duryodhana's mind, entirely comparative and competitive, cannot conceive of such non-dual recognition.
commentary.yogananda: Each name Duryodhana recites — Yuyudhana, Virata, Drupada — represents a divine quality or force arrayed on the side of righteousness in the inner war. Yogananda saw the Pandava side as representing the soul-aligned faculties: courage, loyalty, dharmic determination. The ego catalogues these qualities with fear, recognizing that they are formidable. The spiritual aspirant who has awakened to the higher forces within also recognizes how powerful the dharmic faculties are — and how they pose the final challenge to the reign of the ego.
commentary.goyandka: This verse begins Duryodhana's enumeration of Pandava commanders. The title 'mahāratha' — great chariot-warrior — has a precise military classification in ancient Indian warfare: a mahāratha could single-handedly fight ten thousand ordinary warriors. Drupada is specifically distinguished with this title. Yuyudhana is another name for Sātyaki, the loyal companion of Krishna. Virāṭa is the king of Matsya in whose court the Pandavas spent their year of incognito exile. The listing serves both narrative and didactic purposes, establishing the scale and quality of the forces at Kurukshetra.

verses.sanskrit:
धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् ।
पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः ॥
verses.transliteration:
dhṛṣṭaketuś cekitānaḥ kāśirājaś ca vīryavān
purujit kuntibhojaś ca śaibyaś ca nara-puṅgavaḥ
verses.translation: Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the valiant king of Kashi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Shaibya — the foremost among men.

word_breakdown.meaning: bull among men / foremost of men
Kuntibhoja — king of the Kunti clan, foster-father of Kunti
Shaibya — king of the Shibi clan

commentary.dadaji: The names continue — Dhrishtaketu, Kuntibhoja, Shaibya. Kuntibhoja is particularly poignant: he is the foster-father of Kunti herself, the mother of the Pandavas. Here he fights on her sons' side, yet his very presence on the battlefield means he too may die. Dadaji often reflected on how every name in these opening verses of the Geeta represents a human story — a life, a family, a lineage of devotion and love. The Geeta is not abstract philosophy; it begins with the most concrete human reality: the cost of conflict, the weight of relationships, the grief of war.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The title 'nara-puṅgava' — bull among men — applied to Shaibya is a common Sanskrit honorific. From the standpoint of Advaita Vedanta, what is most significant is not who these warriors are individually, but what they represent collectively: a powerful movement of dharma. In the metaphysical reading, when dharma assembles its forces, it calls forth the best in humanity — the brave, the noble, the courageous. The army of dharma is always composed of 'nara-puṅgavas,' those in whom the human spirit reaches its highest expression.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda identified each group of warriors in these opening verses as corresponding to specific faculties, qualities, or forces within the human psyche. The Pandava commanders collectively represent the powers of the soul — integrity, perception, valor in the service of truth. Kuntibhoja, related to Kunti (who represents devotion), and Shaibya (noble loyalty), suggest that the soul's army draws its strength from devotion, faithfulness, and the noble qualities cultivated through spiritual practice.
commentary.goyandka: The enumeration of warriors in these verses follows the classical style of Sanskrit epic poetry called 'nāmāvalī' — a list of names that serves as homage to the heroes. Dhṛṣṭaketu was the son of Śiśupāla, king of Chedī. Cekitāna was a Yadava warrior. Kāśirāja, the king of Kāśī (Varanasi), is described separately as 'vīryavān' — full of valor. This slight emphasis distinguishes him. Purujit and Kuntibhoja were brothers, maternal uncles of the Pandavas. The verse closes with 'nara-puṅgava,' a term of supreme masculine honor in Vedic culture.

verses.sanskrit:
युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान् ।
सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yudhāmanyuś ca vikrānta uttamaujāś ca vīryavān
saubhadro draupadeyāś ca sarva eva mahārathāḥ
verses.translation: The valiant Yudhamanyu, the mighty Uttamauja, the son of Subhadra (Abhimanyu), and the sons of Draupadi — all of them are great chariot-fighters.

word_breakdown.meaning: valiant / heroic / one who has advanced boldly
Uttamauja — one of supreme vital energy
the sons of Draupadi (Prativindhya and others)

commentary.dadaji: The mention of Saubhadra — Abhimanyu, the young son of Arjuna and Subhadra — carries tremendous poignancy for anyone who knows the Mahabharata. Here he is listed among the great warriors, full of promise and valor. Yet Dadaji, knowing the story, saw in this name a symbol of how war destroys the young and the bright. Abhimanyu would die in the most tragic way — trapped in a formation, surrounded by enemies who broke every rule of honorable combat. The mention of his name here, casual and confident, before the storm of war, is heartbreaking. The Geeta speaks to all such Abhimanyus — the young, the gifted, the brave who face life's great battles.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The verse closes with 'sarva eva mahārathāḥ' — all of them, without exception, are great warriors. This universality is spiritually significant. On the side of dharma, every participant is fully qualified, fully capable. Vedanta teaches that when aligned with truth, every faculty of the human being reaches its highest expression. Contrasted with the Kaurava side, which has brilliant individuals but a compromised foundation, the Pandava side has what Advaita would call 'sāmarthya in alignment with the Absolute' — each person functioning as a full expression of their highest nature.
commentary.yogananda: The sons of Draupadi — the Upapandavas — and Abhimanyu represent the next generation of divine forces. In Yogananda's interpretation, they symbolize the fresh spiritual energies that arise through dedicated practice: new powers of discrimination, new capacities of devotion and concentration that emerge as the inner war progresses. They are 'mahārathas' — great warriors — because these freshly cultivated qualities carry enormous power in the inner spiritual battle. Every deepened meditative state, every new insight, strengthens the soul's army with these young, vigorous forces.
commentary.goyandka: Yudhāmanyu and Uttamauja were twin princes in Drupada's army, loyal Pāñcāla commanders. Saubhadra is Abhimanyu — born of Arjuna and Subhadrā (Krishna's sister), trained personally by Arjuna and schooled even in the womb in the secrets of military formation. The Draupadeyāḥ are the five sons of Draupadī by each of the five Pandavas: Prativindhya, Sutasoma, Śrutakīrti, Śatānīka, and Śrutakarman. The concluding epithet 'sarva eva mahārathāḥ' — every single one a great warrior — emphasizes that this is not a partial list but a comprehensive roster of Pandava excellence.

verses.sanskrit:
अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम ।
नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते ॥
verses.transliteration:
asmākaṃ tu viśiṣṭā ye tān nibodha dvijottama
nāyakā mama sainyasya saṃjñārthaṃ tān bravīmi te
verses.translation: But know also, O best of the twice-born, the distinguished commanders on our side. I name them for your information: the leaders of my army.

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Past participle used as adjective, masculine, nominative, plural

word_breakdown.meaning: O best of the twice-born (addressing Drona, a brāhmaṇa)

commentary.dadaji: After cataloguing the enemy's forces, Duryodhana turns to his own side with the word 'tu' — but, however, on the other hand. This small word reveals the underlying insecurity. He has just described the Pandava army as mighty and filled with warriors equal to Bhima and Arjuna. Now he pivots: 'but on our side there are also distinguished warriors.' He addresses Drona as 'dvijottama' — best of the twice-born — a respectful address. Yet Dadaji noticed that this respect is strategic, not sincere. Duryodhana is trying to reassure himself as much as he is informing Drona. His anxiety drives him to count and recount his own strength.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The phrase 'saṃjñārtham' — for information, for identification — is revealing. Duryodhana frames his listing of commanders as an informational exercise. But why would he need to inform Drona, who knows every warrior on both sides personally? The real audience is Duryodhana himself. He is rehearsing his strengths to manage his own fear. This is the ego's characteristic behavior: when threatened, it lists its assets, counts its resources, catalogs its powers — not to solve the real problem but to temporarily quiet the anxiety. Advaita Vedanta identifies this anxiety as the fundamental mark of a self that has forgotten its infinite nature.
commentary.yogananda: Duryodhana addresses Drona as 'dvijottama' — best of the twice-born. The 'twice-born' refers traditionally to those who have undergone the sacred thread ceremony, a second birth into knowledge and spiritual duty. Yogananda saw deeper meaning: the truly twice-born is one who has had the second birth of spiritual awakening, the entry into Self-knowledge. Duryodhana, addressing Drona with this title, unknowingly identifies the precise quality he himself lacks: he has had the outer birth of nobility, but not the inner birth of wisdom. His enumeration of armies is the activity of the once-born mind.
commentary.goyandka: The conjunction 'tu' (but, however) explicitly signals that Duryodhana is shifting from the opponent's forces to his own. 'Nibodha' — please know, take note — is a polite imperative. Addressing Droṇa as 'dvijottama,' best of the twice-born, acknowledges his Brahmin status and learning while also serving the practical purpose of flattery. The phrase 'mama sainyasya nāyakāḥ' — leaders of my army — is notable: Duryodhana says 'my army,' not 'our army' or 'the Kaurava army.' This proprietary use reveals his psychology: he regards everything, including the army of an entire civilization, as personally his.

verses.sanskrit:
भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः ।
अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च ॥
verses.transliteration:
bhavān bhīṣmaś ca karṇaś ca kṛpaś ca samitiñjayaḥ
aśvatthāmā vikarṇaś ca saumadattis tathaiva ca
verses.translation: Yourself (Drona), Bhishma, Karna, Kripa who is ever victorious in battle, Ashvatthama, Vikarna, and the son of Somadatta (Bhurishrava).

word_breakdown.root: bha + vat (honorific from bhū, to be)

word_breakdown.meaning: Bhishma — the great grandsire, sworn to a terrible vow of celibacy
Karna — son of the Sun-god, great archer and rival of Arjuna
ever victorious in battle — epithet of Kripa
Ashvatthama — son of Drona, one of the chiranjivis (immortals)

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana lists his own side's great warriors, and it is a formidable list. Bhishma — the greatest living warrior, invincible, the very symbol of dharmic commitment. Drona — the supreme teacher of warfare. Karna — the most generous, most skilled, most tragic figure in the epic, Arjuna's equal and secret brother. Each name here is extraordinary. Dadaji observed that Duryodhana had no shortage of great allies — his failure was not lack of power but lack of wisdom and righteousness. A side can have every advantage and still lose when its foundation is adharma. The Geeta teaches that dharma is the ultimate force.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The list of Kaurava commanders is remarkable for another reason: nearly every one of them privately knew that the Pandavas were in the right. Bhishma knew it. Drona knew it. Even Karna, in his most honest moments, acknowledged it. Yet they fought for the Kaurava side out of obligation, loyalty, debt, and ego. This is the tragedy of noble qualities placed in service of an unworthy cause. Advaita Vedanta would say that their clarity of perception (they saw the truth) was not matched by the freedom to act on that clarity — they were bound by conditioning, by samskāras, by the weight of social obligation.
commentary.yogananda: On the level of inner symbolism, the Kaurava commanders represent formidable ego-forces: Bhishma is the power of unbreakable habit and iron-willed resistance to change; Drona is the crystallized intellectual pattern that has been teaching ego-strategies for years; Karna is the brilliant but misdirected energy, loyal to the wrong master. These forces are powerful precisely because they have been cultivated and trained. The spiritual aspirant who undertakes the inner battle must face exactly these: ancient habits, established mental patterns, and misplaced loyalties that seem noble but serve the ego.
commentary.goyandka: Drona is listed first among the Kaurava commanders — addressed as 'bhavān,' the honorific 'you' — because Duryodhana is speaking directly to him. The epithet for Kṛpa is 'samitiñjaya' — victorious in all assemblies and battles — which is rare; Kṛpa was considered practically invulnerable. Aśvatthāmā, Drona's son, is listed here; his later role in the post-war massacre of the sleeping Pandava camp makes this listing particularly fraught. Saumadatti — Bhūriśravas, grandson of Bāhlika — was a Kuru aristocrat of the highest standing. Each name listed here carries the weight of entire lineages.

verses.sanskrit:
अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः ।
नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
anye ca bahavaḥ śūrā mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ
nānā-śastra-praharaṇāḥ sarve yuddha-viśāradāḥ
verses.translation: And there are many other heroes who have risked their lives for my sake, armed with various weapons — all experienced and skilled in battle.

word_breakdown.meaning: for my sake / for my cause

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Compound past participle, masculine, nominative, plural
word_breakdown.meaning: those who have given up their lives / risked their lives
armed with various weapons / wielders of diverse arms
experts in warfare / those skilled and experienced in battle

commentary.dadaji: The phrase 'mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ' — who have given up their lives for my sake — reveals Duryodhana's deepest self-perception. He does not say 'for the sake of Hastinapura' or 'for dharma' or 'for the protection of the people.' He says 'for me.' This is pure ego speaking. Dadaji often noted that the greatest violence in human history has been committed not for God, not for truth, not even for nation — but for the aggrandizement of individual ego. 'For my sake' — how much suffering has been created in the world by those three words. The Geeta's teaching is precisely the antidote: act not for 'me' but for the divine will.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The ego's relationship with its followers is clearly expressed in 'mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ' — they have sacrificed their lives for me. The ego always surrounds itself with those who have given themselves to its cause. And it draws security from this — from the multitude willing to die for it. But Vedanta points out: no amount of external support can remedy the fundamental insecurity of an ego that has forgotten its real nature. Duryodhana's entire speech is a cry of anxiety dressed in the language of strength. He counts warriors as others count beads — hoping the number will equal safety.
commentary.yogananda: These unnamed warriors — 'anye ca bahavaḥ' — represent the vast population of conditioned habits, desires, and impulses that serve the ego without question. Yogananda identified this as the 'army of tendencies' — the countless saṃskāras and vāsanās accumulated over many lifetimes that immediately take the side of the ego when challenged. They are 'yuddha-viśāradāḥ' — battle-hardened — because they have been fighting the soul's freedom for lifetimes. The spiritual seeker recognizes these unnamed forces as the most difficult to overcome: the habits so deeply ingrained that they do not even have individual faces.
commentary.goyandka: This verse serves as a summary conclusion to Duryodhana's enumeration of his own forces. 'Anye ca bahavaḥ śūrāḥ' — and many others who are heroes — acknowledges that his list has been selective, representing only the most distinguished commanders. The comprehensive description follows: they bear diverse weapons (nānā-śastra-praharaṇāḥ) and are all experts in war (yuddha-viśāradāḥ). The phrase 'mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ' is a warrior's highest praise for his troops — those who have pledged their lives. Commentators note that this phrase, while honorable in a military context, also exposes Duryodhana's proprietary view of the war.

verses.sanskrit:
अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम् ।
पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
aparyāptaṃ tad asmākaṃ balaṃ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam
paryāptaṃ tv idam eteṣāṃ balaṃ bhīmābhirakṣitam
verses.translation: Our army, protected by Bhishma, is unlimited (or: insufficient); whereas their army, protected by Bhima, is limited (or: sufficient).

word_breakdown.root: a (not) + pari + √āp (to reach, to be sufficient)
word_breakdown.meaning: unlimited / immeasurable; OR: not sufficient / inadequate (dual interpretation)
limited / measurable; OR: sufficient / adequate (dual interpretation)

commentary.dadaji: This verse contains one of the most fascinating ambiguities in the entire Geeta. The words 'aparyāptam' and 'paryāptam' each carry two opposite meanings. 'Aparyāptam' can mean 'unlimited, immeasurable' (our army is unlimited — a boast) or 'insufficient, inadequate' (our army is not enough — a fear). Translators have debated this for centuries. Dadaji loved this ambiguity: it perfectly captures Duryodhana's inner state. He is simultaneously boasting and secretly afraid. He says one thing but fears the opposite. This double meaning embedded in the Sanskrit is not accidental — it is the Geeta showing us the nature of the ego: always projecting strength while secretly trembling.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The famous ambiguity of 'aparyāptam' and 'paryāptam' is a gift to the commentator. The verse can be read as Duryodhana's boast: 'Our army protected by Bhishma is limitless; their army protected by Bhima is limited.' Or as his deepest anxiety laid bare: 'Our force is insufficient; their force is more than enough.' Both readings are grammatically valid. Advaita Vedanta would say: the ego always speaks in this double register. Its confident assertions carry the shadow of its deepest fears. The only consciousness that speaks with undivided clarity is the Self — the Ātman that knows no limitation and harbors no secret dread.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda highlighted this verse as a profound psychological portrait. The ego — represented by Duryodhana — is caught between grandiosity and dread. This is the characteristic oscillation of the unenlightened mind: 'I am unlimited!' covers 'I am afraid I am not enough.' The spiritual teaching embedded here is that this oscillation itself, this constant alternation between inflation and deflation, is the mark of ego-consciousness. The soul, established in the Self, knows neither inflation nor deflation. It is 'pūrṇam' — complete — always. The Geeta's entire teaching aims to shift the student from Duryodhana's fearful oscillation to the Ātman's serene fullness.
commentary.goyandka: This verse has generated more commentary than almost any other in the first chapter due to the double meaning of 'aparyāptam' and 'paryāptam.' Śaṅkarācārya, Madhusūdana Sarasvatī, and other major commentators have each chosen different readings. Śrīdhara takes 'aparyāptam' as 'immeasurable/unlimited' and reads the verse as Duryodhana's boast. Others like Keśavakāśmīrin take it as 'insufficient' and read the verse as Duryodhana's private admission of inadequacy to Drona alone. Goyandka's Gita Press commentary follows the reading that sees this as Duryodhana's boast of Kaurava strength, while acknowledging the alternate interpretation.

verses.sanskrit:
अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः ।
भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि ॥
verses.transliteration:
ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu yathā-bhāgam avasthitāḥ
bhīṣmam evābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi
verses.translation: Therefore all of you, positioned in your respective places in the battle formation, must protect Bhishma in particular — all of you together.

word_breakdown.meaning: in the passages / in the strategic positions / in the avenues of the formation

word_breakdown.root: yathā (as, according to) + bhāga (share, portion, position)
word_breakdown.meaning: each in his respective position / according to one's assigned place
you (honorific plural) — addressing the assembled commanders

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana ends his speech with a military command: protect Bhishma above all others. This reveals how deeply he knows that his entire strategy rests on the invincibility of Bhishma. Without Bhishma standing firm at the center, the Kaurava cause would crumble. Dadaji saw in this a spiritual lesson: when we build our lives on an external foundation — however grand and invincible it may seem — we are always vulnerable. Bhishma could fall. All externals can fall. The only truly indestructible foundation is the Self. The warrior who fights from the center of the Ātman cannot be defeated — for death itself has no power over one established in the Self.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Duryodhana's final instruction is 'protect Bhishma.' In the Vedantic allegory, Bhishma — whose name means 'one of terrible resolve' — represents the power of deeply entrenched conditioned patterns, the ancient vows that bind the individual even against their better judgment. Duryodhana is commanding all his forces to protect these patterns, to keep them intact. This is precisely what the ego does: it marshals all available resources to protect its deepest conditioning, its most fundamental assumptions about itself and reality. The work of Vedanta — of true self-inquiry — is the exact opposite: to examine and dissolve the Bhishmas of our inner life.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda saw in Bhishma the principle of deep karmic obligation — the force of past promises, ancestral duties, and conditioned loyalties that bind the individual to an old order even when wisdom points elsewhere. Duryodhana commands his forces to protect this principle above all else. The ego's deepest instinct is to preserve its oldest patterns. 'Guard the pattern! Guard the habit! Guard what has always been!' The entire spiritual life involves the gradual unwinding of this command — learning to release what was sworn to in past lives and past states of consciousness, and opening to the freedom of the present moment.
commentary.goyandka: The military significance of this command is concrete and precise. 'Ayaneṣu' refers to the various avenues and passages within the battle formation — the flanks, the center, the rear guard. Duryodhana instructs each commander to remain 'yathā-bhāgam' — in his assigned position — while simultaneously focusing all protective attention on Bhishma. This was sound military strategy: Bhishma was the supreme commander and his protection was essential. The Kaurava formation was built around him. Commentators note that this verse, even as military instruction, also reveals Duryodhana's anxiety: he must explicitly command what should be natural to loyal warriors.

verses.sanskrit:
सञ्जय उवाच ।
तस्य सञ्जनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः ।
सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान् ॥
verses.transliteration:
sañjaya uvāca
tasya sañjanayan harṣaṃ kuru-vṛddhaḥ pitāmahaḥ
siṃha-nādaṃ vinadyoccaiḥ śaṅkhaṃ dadhmau pratāpavān
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: Then Bhishma, the great grandsire of the Kuru clan, the most glorious and mighty one, roared loudly like a lion and blew his conch shell, filling Duryodhana's heart with joy.

commentary.dadaji: With Bhishma's lion-roar and the thunder of his conch, the Geeta's battlefield comes fully alive. Dadaji loved this moment: Bhishma, the oldest, the greatest, the most invincible warrior alive, responds to his grandson's anxiety not with words but with action — a roar, a conch. He is saying: 'Do not fear. I am here.' The sound of the conch was the ancient call to sacred action. In the Vedic tradition, the conch removes fear and announces the presence of divine power. Bhishma's blowing of the conch is an act of compassion toward Duryodhana — whatever his errors, Bhishma will stand by his pledge. This is the complex, heartbreaking loyalty that runs through the entire epic.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The narrative returns from Duryodhana's anxious speech to Sanjaya's external description. We move from the inner world of Duryodhana's fear and calculation back to the outward spectacle: Bhishma roaring like a lion, blowing his conch. Sanjaya describes Bhishma as 'pratāpavān' — the glorious, the blazing. This is the language of awe. Even in describing the Kaurava side, Sanjaya cannot help but use terms of glory. From the Vedantic standpoint, Bhishma's greatness is real — his error is not lack of power but misuse of it, placing extraordinary energy in service of an unworthy cause. This is the tragedy of dharmic power allied with adharma.
commentary.yogananda: The lion's roar of Bhishma represents the deep, primal sound of the ego's ancient fortress announcing its readiness for battle. The conch — the śaṅkha — is a sacred instrument whose sound resonates at a frequency that clears the atmosphere and commands attention. In the inner war, this moment represents the crystallization of resistance: the deepest habits, the oldest patterns, the most entrenched ego-structures announce themselves with full force. This is not merely the beginning of a physical battle but the sounding of the innermost conflict in every human soul — the conflict between the self that must be transcended and the Self that awaits discovery.
commentary.goyandka: The verse marks the formal opening of hostilities. Bhishma is described by three great titles: 'kuru-vṛddhaḥ' (elder of the Kurus), 'pitāmahaḥ' (grandsire — technically great-grandsire of both Pandavas and Kauravas), and 'pratāpavān' (the gloriously powerful). The 'siṃha-nādam' — lion's roar — was a recognized battle cry of the highest warriors, signaling readiness and striking fear in opponents. 'Dadhmau' uses the Sanskrit perfect tense, indicating completed action with present relevance: he blew and the sound is still resonating. This verse triggers the cascading exchange of conch-sounds that fills the next several verses and formally inaugurates the Kurukshetra war.
